Matt Damon and Chris Pratt look very different to me, but I cannot tell you what it is that makes Matt Damon look like Matt Damon and Chris Pratt look like Chris Pratt.

Farmers in the US have long dominated world markets, but in recent years Brazil has been catching up.
Take soybeans, for example; Brazil is already the world's second-largest producer and is soon expected to pass the US.
NPR's Greg Allen has the first of two reports.
Today, investments American farmers are making in Brazil.
There are few places in America where farming is more important than Iowa.
It leads the nation in corn, soybean and hog production.
In fact, it's a state with more hogs than people.
Here in Clay County, in Iowa's northwest corner, there are about 17,000 people, but more than 100,000 hogs.
(Soundbite of someone walking in snow)
Many of those hogs are raised here on Dick Gilmore's farm near the town of Rossie.
Gilmore walks over newly fallen snow on land his great-grandfather homesteaded more than a century ago.
With his full beard, sunglasses and long, gray braid, Gilmore looks more like a biker than a successful hog farmer.
In fact, he's both.
Along with his brother, Charles, Dick Gilmore collects Harleys and raises some 30,000 hogs each year in confinement buildings spread out over 50 miles.
This is a sow farm.
(Soundbite of metal being banged)
So this is where we breed and farrow.
(Soundbite of metal being banged)
Gilmore says his hog farm used to be considered big.
But no longer.
Industry consolidation has wiped out most small farms, and huge hog confinement operations are now the norm in Iowa and across the country.
But when it came time to expand, Gilmore says he and his brother decided to invest in a new farm, not here, but some 5,500 miles south in Brazil.
Gilmore says one trip to Brazil was all it took to convince him.
It's a real eye-opener.
I've been told, just to paint a visual picture, that if we go down the Mississippi River and take everything east, taking off a little bit, like taking off Florida and maybe a little bit more.

The Gilmore brothers were among the first to invest in a new company based just a few miles away here in the town of Royal.
Royal is a town surrounded by corn and soybean farms with fewer than 500 people.
A few businesses in low-slung brick buildings are clustered along Main Street.
But appearances can be deceiving.
One of those buildings is home to Brazil Iowa Farms, a $26-million company that owns and raises crops on 23,000 acres of land in western Bahia.
Its founder and CEO is commodity trading adviser David Cruz.
Cruz sums up Brazil's appeal to American farmers in two words: cheap land.
Improved, ready-to-farm land in Brazil goes for just $600 an acre, a small fraction of what it costs in Iowa and across the Midwest.
Cruz says his company offers a way for farmers to invest in Brazil without having to move there and till the land themselves.
`Gee, do I buy this $4,500-an-acre land out s--to add my operation here, or do I globalize a little bit?'
There are now more than a dozen American-owned farms operating in western Bahia and more in other parts of Brazil.
Many are corporate farms, but over the last decade Brazil has also become a destination for a small, but growing number of expatriate Americans who want in on the agriculture boom there.
Phil Warnken knows many of them.
Warnken is a former University of Missouri professor and an expert on Brazilian agriculture who now runs a consulting company, AgBrazil.
Sort of a typical situation would be the family owns a good-sized operation, let's say, in the Corn Belt or the Wheat Belt.
They have a son who's recently graduated from Kansas State or Iowa State.
And there's simply no opportunities for that son if he wants to farm, even though the family may have a good source of capital.
These families are putting their sons down in Brazil, and the sons are doing very, very well; in fact, sometimes even better than the home farm in the US.
Along with the low cost of land, Brazil also enjoys other competitive advantages.
One is the low cost of labor, a big factor in producing cotton.
Another is the climate.
In Brazil, Warnken says, while soybeans do well, cotton positively thrives.
Year in, year out, Brazil can produce three times as much cotton per acre as can the US farm.
This is very, very profitable.
Even though the cost of production per acre may be the same, they're getting three times as much cotton.
